Title: the foetal kick catalyst

Scene: expected the surprise, and therefore not have been surprised, but as it is, I didn’t know, and therefore my surprise should be unsurprising.
Penny: Hey, have you ever heard of the Van Nuys Comic-Con?
I got asked to sign autographs there.
Well, it could be for the monkey movie. It could be my haemorrhoid commercial. The list does not go on.
It doesn’t matter. I’m not doing it.
You just said yourself, it’s sad.
I don’t know.
I guess it wouldn’t hurt to meet some fans and make a little extra money.
Oh, yeah.
What’s all this?
Okay. Leonard, it’s sweet you’re excited about this, but it’ll be a miracle if one person asks for my autograph.
Who’s that?
Oh, there’s so much I want to change.
Really? I feel like I’m selling candy so our team can get new uniforms.
Alright, why not five and ten bucks?
Hey, that guy’s looking over here.
I don’t know. Be cool. He’s coming. He’s coming. Hi.
Well, thanks.
Your love confuses me.
Okay. Who do I make it out to?
Okay.
That did not clear things up.
What’s your name?
Okay.
Been hearing that a lot today.
Yep, there they are.
Here you go.
Well, go ahead. He’s right over there.
Hello.
Thank you.
I assume we’re still talking about the movies, but after today, who knows.
Oh, sure.
Leonard…
Yeah, he really is.
And he started to slowly wear me down.
Yeah, except the river kept showing me his Pokémon cards.
I think it’s hot.
You know, once, I proposed to him.
Yeah, that’s gonna cost you later.
Leonard: ‭Yeah. It’s a dinky little convention where they sell collectibles and get sad D-list celebrities to appear. Why?
That’s awesome. Is this for Serial Ape-ist?
When is it?
What? Why not?
Yeah, but it’s not pathetic, that’s where I draw the line. Come on, we’ll have fun.
You’ll have nerds fawning all over you. If you don’t love that, this marriage is in trouble.
Yeah. Wow, An appearance by George Lucas… ‘s dermatologist. Oh, I want that autograph.
Oh, everything we need for your autograph session, head shots, markers.
Are you kidding? I once paid twenty dollars for Theo Sassler’s signature.
Oh, I don’t even know. I just liked his name. Theo Sassler. Okay, and look at this. I even got a change maker. How much change you want, little lady?
Yeah, well, if it’s a dollar, you’re in luck.
Never been on this side of the table before. I feel powerful.
Okay, so it’s four seventy-five for a signed black-and-white and nine ninety-five for a colour.
Well, I brought my moneymaker. Let me shake it.
Oh. You think he’s your first autograph?
Would you like an autograph?
That’ll be four seventy-five.
But I-I-I, oh. Nothing about that was good.
Okay, let’s keep it moving.
Should’ve punched that guy.
Why do you do that? Can’t you let me have my moment?
No. She cannot kiss. What is wrong with you people?
No, no, no. It’s not okay.
I’m her husband.
I am.
Well, she moved in across the hall.
Like a river carves a canyon.
That’s right. I’m her change daddy.
And that is how a short asthmatic scientist landed a stone cold fox.
The third time I did it in skywriting, but she never looked up.
Yeah. I said no.
I just wanted to make her work for it.
She makes more money than I do.
Amy: You know, with us living together, maybe we could think about having people over.
You know what I meant.
I’m sorry I mentioned it.
What’s going on here?
Well, that’s so nice. Who’s coming?
You mean the Romanian lady on the second floor?
That’s an odd mix of people.
You never went into that haunted house.
Well, thank you, Sheldon. This is a fun surprise.
Well, that’s not a surprise at all. I mean, if I knew you were good at surprises, I would have
There’s nothing to be afraid of, Sheldon.
Been 15 minutes. Just sayin’.
How old was it
Hi, Stuart.
Oh, they’re pretty. Thank you.
Things didn’t work out?
Uh, no. He, he just means that you were the first people we thought of.
Stuart, you know you’re one of our favourite people.
No, Stuart, don’t.
We’re so sorry.
Cheers.
Maybe I can get a little help putting some of this stuff away.
Sheldon: We have people over all the time. We have the maintenance people, the pizza delivery man, that UPS driver who feels the need to ask how parts of me are hanging.

All right, fine. Let’s say that we were to entertain people. What type of gathering did you have in mind? Huh? A meal? Lunch? Brunch? Dinner? Afternoon tea? A formal tea? Hmm? Is it a party? And if so, what kind of party? Is it a cocktail party? A Tupperware party? Ooh, is it a surprise party? Oh, I hope it’s not a West Coast party, ’cause according to the man on the radio, a West Coast party don’t stop.
Oh, don’t be. You get your hopes up, I knock them down. That’s called teamwork.
You expressed an interest in having people over, and I feel I dismissed it too quickly. So, I took matters into my own hands, and I arranged a brunch.
Oh, uh, Stuart, Bert from the geology lab, and Mrs. Petrescu from downstairs.
Yes. Oh, fun story, she grew up with ten siblings. Or possibly penguins. Her English is atrocious.
Well, for our first time hosting, I thought it would be wise to conduct a trial run. You know, like how I practiced for that Halloween haunted house by going into the bathroom at the bus station.
You never saw what jumped out at me at the bus station.
Oh. Well, the real surprise is how surprised you are that I’m great at surprises.
Don’t get me all randy. Guests are on the way.
The average cork speed is 25 miles per hour. If that is too fast around a school, it is certainly too fast around a kitchen.
Okay. I can do this. Just give me a moment… Oh! Mimosas coming up.
Would you like one, Mrs. Petrescu?
She’s learning English from TV.
Stuart, this is Bert from the Caltech geology lab, and this is Mrs. Petrescu from downstairs.
So until Amy’s apartment is fixed, she and I are living here together.
This is it. You are the practice round.
You know, exactly. We’ve never thrown a brunch before, and I wanted to work out all the kinks.
Hmm. You see, your words sound reasonable, but your face looks angry. Help me out here, this is not where I shine.
Okay, now, see, you look sincere, but your words are completely false. I’m glad we did this test run, these brunches are wild.
Oh. Thank you.
Well, no, that’s not true. I mean, sometimes it’s Koothrappali. But we’re not supposed to say that ’cause he’s a minority.
Stuart, wait. I do know what it feels like to be left out.

All right, this is about me and him, you’re not part of it. Stuart, perhaps we do take you for granted, and that is not acceptable. Please know that you truly are a valuable member of our social group.
You know, in fact, I’d like to propose a toast. To Stuart. A fine man, a good friend and a wonderful guest.
Do you know what else I love about you?
Your handwriting is impeccable.
No, I mean it. I mean it. It’s like you have the soul of a label maker.
Hmm?
You never know when two pieces of paper might temporarily need fastening in the top left corner.
You know, it turns out, you can hurt people just as well without ’em.
Oh, calm down. I already put away five of these. You see? No muss, no fuss, not a single cuss.
Howard: That’s a kick. That’s an actual kick.
I felt a kick. There’s a baby in there.
Oh, I mean, I know you’re pregnant. I just never connected the idea of pregnancy and you actually having a baby.
Oh, God, we are not ready to have an infant in this house. We don’t have a crib, we don’t have diapers, we’re not baby-proofed. Anyone can just walk in off the street and lift our toilet lids!
Do we? Look at you. Willy Wonka would roll you to the juicing room.
Are we even in a good school…? Ow!
Hi.
Oh, we went and did a little shopping for the baby.
You’re gonna love it.
Okay, well, I may have gone a bit overboard, but you can’t put a price on safety.
But it’s the safest crib you can buy. And if you don’t like it, we can return it.
In our new minivan. Hey, what’s for lunch?
It’s for the baby, and I didn’t buy it. The dealer loaned it to me for a 24-hour test drive.
The guy at the dealership said they’re not just for moms anymore.
It’s got a rearview camera, there’s a DVD player, oh, and check this out. It’s like we’re living in the future.
Imagine this, you’ve got the baby in one hand, groceries in the other, and you’re thinking, how am I gonna open this trunk?
You don’t need my help when you can open the trunk with a simple kick of the foot.
Uh, maybe it was more of a circle?
Yes.
See? Easy. And look at all this cargo space. Now we’ll get the crib out and you can take it for a test-drive. I’m telling you, this van is gonna be… uuh-uuh, uuh-uuh.
Oh, yeah, oh, anyway, let’s just get in and see if the GPS can take us to the nearest emergency room.
Aaaaah. What was I thinking? Wolowitzes are not a lifting people. We tip the lifting people.
You’re gonna feel terrible when I’m in a wheelchair. Which, by the way, would fit easily in the back of this award-winning minivan.
You’re right. It sells itself.
If childbirth is half this bad, you are so screwed. Are we there yet?
Why is it taking so long?
I’m in too much pain to watch cartoo… oh, this is a good one.
Bernadette: What are you doing?
Oh, yeah, that’s where I put it.
Which MIT did you go to?
Howie, we have time to do all that stuff.
The next person kicking you will be me. Good night.
I warned you, and I did it.
Hey, where you been?
You bought a crib without me?
Sounds expensive.
Fine.
You bought a minivan?
I don’t want to drive that. It’s such a mom car.
They thought it at the ultrasound, why not at the car dealership?
I’m probably thinking, where’s my husband, and why isn’t he helping me?
It’s weird that guy thought you were a couple.
Oh, is it your back?
Do we really have to sit for hours in the emergency room? They’re just gonna give you ice and Advil like last time.
Fine, we’ll go to the E.R. Just stop selling me on the van.
I was hoping it’d be quieter.
Soon.
Fine. I’ll buy the stupid van.
Raj: Wait till you see the crib we found.
Yeah, it’s the highest rated one on the market. I wouldn’t even call it a crib, I’d call it a Fortress of Solitude for babies.
Though if you did, it’s more zeroes than you’re expecting.
Though we did ding up the back pretty good with the crib, so you might have bought a minivan.
Then again, he did think you were my husband.
Hey, show her the trunk. Show her the trunk.
No, it’s a gentle kick, you’re doing it wrong. Here. Give me those.
You have to admit, it’s a pretty smooth ride.
I’ve been babysitting him way longer than you have.
Guy: It has got to be one of the worst things I’ve ever seen in my life.
Daniel: I have to ask. Were you trying to be that bad, or are you just a terrible actress?
Bert: I once left orange juice in my fridge so long, it tasted like a mimosa.
It’s hard to say. I don’t remember much after I drank it.
Eh, we watched Sheldon try to open a bottle for 15 minutes.
I lived with my old girlfriend. She was a geologist, too.
I came home from work one day and she had taken everything. I’m warning you, hide your good rocks.
This is the best blintz I’ve ever had.
It almost makes up for the incredibly awkward turn things took earlier.
I know how it feels, too.
Mrs Petrescu: Yes. Drink is fun and good friends, Applebee’s.
TV, good. Now back to you.
15 minutes can save you 15% or more on car insurance.
My sister’s husband took all her things, too. Story at eleven.
Cheers. Filmed before a live studio audience.
Stuart: Anybody else coming to this thing?
Really, no one else is coming?
So, I’m like a lab rat before your real friends come over?
You know what, I, I, I think I’m just gonna go.
No, I consider you and Sheldon like my family, and I’m not even sure you think of me as a friend. You have any idea how that feels?
I’m always the last one anybody thinks of.
You know what I love about you?
You never leave the house without a paper clip.
I also love how you never use swear words.
Jeff: My favourite part is your shower scene.
I even have a screen grab on my phone.
Awkward guy: You think I could get a picture of us?
And, uh, could you be giving me a kiss?
But how did you get her to go out with you?
Hang on. This guy’s telling me how he got the Serial Ape-ist girl to marry him.
Oh. Whoa. I didn’t know you can propose to the same person so many times.
Red-haired guy: This guy? But he’s wearing a change maker.
Hang on. Is she just with you because you’re rich?
